questions.text: A 42-year-old patient, a singer by profession, has been vigorously practising for an important concert. He subsequently developed a hoarse voice. On fiberoptic laryngoscopy, he was found to have adduction of the false vocal cords while phonating. What is the name of this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of Dysphonia plica ventricularis (ventricular dysphonia).

  • Here, voice is produced by the ventricular folds (false cords), which have taken over the function of the true cords.
  • Voice is rough, low-pitched, and unpleasant.
  • Indirect laryngoscopy - false cords are seen to approximate partially or completely.
  • It is of two types
    1. Functional Type - Psychogenic. Here, the voice begins normally but soon becomes rough.
    2. Secondary to laryngeal disorders.

Explanation for other options:

Phonasthenia (Option B): Also called "vocal fatigue", this is a functional voice disorder without anatomical abnormalities. Patients complain of voice tiredness, but there's no false cord phonation or structural change.

Spasmodic dysphonia (Option C): A neurological voice disorder characterised by involuntary spasms of the vocal cords, leading to a strained or strangled voice. It doesn't involve false cord phonation and is not typically triggered by vocal overuse.

Mogiphonia (Option D): A rare term used to describe difficulty initiating phonation, especially in emotional or psychological conditions. It's often psychogenic, unlike the compensatory physiological phonation seen in plica ventricularis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has a high-pitched voice. His fiberoptic laryngoscopy is normal. The clinician has advised him to undergo speech therapy, in which he is asked to phonate while pulling the thyroid cartilage downwards and pressing it backwards. What is the name of this manoeuvre for speech therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of Puberphonia.

  • Gutzmann's pressure test is the manoeuvre for this speech therapy
  • Normally, a childhood voice has a higher pitch.
  • When the larynx matures at puberty, vocal cords lengthen and the voice changes to one of a lower pitch. This is a feature exclusive to males.
  • Failure of this change leads to persistence of childhood high-pitched voice and is called
  • Treatment - pressing the thyroid prominence in a backwards and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords, and a low tone voice can be produced (Gutzmann's pressure test).
  • The prognosis is good.
  • If the patient is not relieved with speech therapy, then Type III thyroplasty is done.

Explanation for other options:

Heimlich manoeuvre (Option A): An emergency procedure used to treat upper airway obstruction (choking) by applying abdominal thrusts to expel a foreign object.

Muller's manoeuvre (Option C): A forced inspiratory effort against a closed glottis used to assess upper airway collapsibility, often during sleep studies.

Valsalva manoeuvre (Option D): A forced expiratory effort against a closed airway used in cardiac and ENT exams (e.g., equalising middle ear pressure, assessing autonomic function).

questions.text:
Ritesh, a 32-year-old Mathematics teacher, has b=een teaching in a public school for the last 12 years. Lately, he has been taking frequent, long, and uninterrupted sessions before the final examinations of students. He has been complaining of hoarseness of voice for the last 1 month. His laryngeal endoscopy picture is given in the image.

What would be the best management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Voice rest and Proton pump inhibitors would be the best management for this patient with vocal nodules.

  • Commonly seen in: teachers, singers/ actors, due to overuse and improper use of voice.
  • Laryngopharyngeal reflux is also a contributing factor.
  • Heaping up of epithelium in the interarytenoid area is seen in pachydermia laryngiscaused by laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR).
  • First line - Speech therapy or voice rest.
  • PPI is also given for GERD-related complications
  • Microlaryngeal surgery for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults.
  • Most of these cases have silent laryngopharyngeal reflux (asymptomatic). So, PPI always adds value to the treatment.

Explanation for other options:

Voice Rest (Option A): Incomplete without addressing possible reflux (via PPIs), nodules may persist or recur.

CO��� Laser (Option B): Used for precise excision in neoplastic lesions, papillomas, or polyps. Not first-line for vocal nodules, especially in the absence of malignancy or a large mass.

Microlaryngeal Surgery (Option C): Surgical removal of nodules under a microscope. Reserved only for non-responders to conservative management (voice therapy + PPI). Surgery without vocal retraining risks recurrence.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child comes to the emergency department with stridor and respiratory distress for the last 6 hours. On Direct laryngoscopy, the vocal cords are found to be immobile and lying in the median position. Which of the following would not be part of the management strategy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of bilateral abductor palsy of the vocal cords of idiopathic origin. But, injection thyroplasty is typically used for unilateral adductor paralysis, where the goal is to medialize a paralysed cord to improve voice.

  • In bilateral abductor palsy, cords are already too close (median or paramedian position), and medialization would worsen airway obstruction. So, it is contraindicated in this setting.
  • Various temporary fillers with varying durations of efficacy are available.
  • These cause swelling of the cord and help in its medialization.

Temporary fillers:

  1. Calcium hydroxyapatite (1-2 years)
  2. Collagen (6-9 months)
  3. Hyaluronic acid (4-9 months)
  4. Carboxymethylcellulose (2-3 months)
  5. Autologous fat, Teflon, silicon - used in past.

Explanation for other options:

questions.text: A patient suffering from chronic recurrent heartburn, epigastric pain has developed a hoarse voice for the last month. The laryngeal fiberoptic laryngoscopy has revealed the congestion and mamillation of mucosa in the interarytenoid area. What is the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic recurrent heartburn and epigastric pain are suggestive of gastro-oesophageal reflux.
  • GERD (gastro-oesophageal reflux disease) → LPR → posterior part of larynx constantly bathed by acid juices from the stomach → chronic irritation of the affected area → vocal nodules, pachydermia laryngis, Reinke's oedema, keratosis larynx.
  • Pachydermia laryngis is a heaping up of epithelium in the interarytenoid region. It is not premalignant.
  • Treatment: Lifestyle changes, speech therapy, PPIs, and managing reflux aggressively.

Explanation for other options:

Reinke's oedema (Option A) is a polypoid degeneration of the vocal cord, seen as bilateral, symmetrical, fusiform swelling of the vocal cords on laryngoscopy.

Keratosis of the larynx (Option B) is a localised epithelial hyperplasia involving the upper surface of one or both cords. It is premalignant.

Laryngeal pseudosulcus (Option D) is not attached to the underlying tissues, whereas a true vocal cord sulcus is adherent to the underlying tissues of the vocal cord. It refers to the appearance of a fold parallel to the free edge of the vocal cord.

questions.text: A singer has undergone thyroid surgery 1 month ago. Her recovery has been satisfactory except that she is unable to sing higher notes now. What is the possible nerve injury that could have happened during the thyroid surgery of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paralysis of the superior laryngeal nerve causes paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle and ipsilateral anaesthesia of the larynx above the vocal cord.
  • Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cord, which is supplied by the external branch of the SLN.
  • Paralysis of this muscle leads to bowing down of the vocal cords and hence loss of pitch of voice, with decreased ability to sing.

Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (Option A):
The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. It plays a critical role in the abduction and adduction of the vocal cords. Injury to this nerve typically results in hoarseness or a breathy voice, but it does not significantly affect the ability to produce high-pitched sounds. Therefore, it is not the likely nerve involved in the specific complaint of loss of higher notes.

Vagus Nerve (Option B):
The vagus nerve is the parent nerve of both the recurrent and superior laryngeal nerves. A proximal vagus nerve injury can lead to broad dysfunction, including dysphagia, aspiration, and more generalised voice changes. It is less likely to present with an isolated deficit like difficulty with high-pitched singing, which points to a more localised nerve injury.

Glossopharyngeal Nerve (Option C):
The glossopharyngeal nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the pharynx and taste sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue. It is not involved in vocal cord movement or pitch modulation and hence, is not relevant to the patient's specific vocal complaint.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient suffering from thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy. During surgery, both sides recurrent laryngeal nerves were damaged. Which of the following will be the procedure needed in this case in future?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type II thyroplasty will be the procedure needed in this case of bilateral abductor palsy in future.

  • The immediate treatment will be emergency tracheostomy. (Option A ruled out)
  • Then we wait for 6 months. If the patient shows no recovery, then the treatment of choice is vocal cord lateralisation (type 2 thyroplasty).
  • It is also called suture cordopexy of the vocal cord.
  • The Kashima operation is also useful. In this surgery, a CO2 laser is used to separate the membranous and cartilaginous parts of the vocal cords so that there is some space created for the airway.
  • Woodman's operation is an arytenoidectomy by open approach. This can also be advised

choices.text: Respiratory distress with poor quality of voice
Respiratory distress with stridor and normal voice

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient suffering from thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy. During surgery, both sides recurrent laryngeal nerves were damaged. What are the expected post-operative symptoms of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Respiratory distress with stridor and normal voice is the classic presentation of bilateral abductor cord paralysis following bilateral RLN injury.

  • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury causes bilateral abductor paralysis of the vocal cords.
  • The posterior cricoarytenoid (PCA) muscles, which are the only abductors, are paralysed.
  • However, the cricothyroid muscle, which is an adductor supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), remains intact.

As a result, both vocal cords lie in the paramedian position, partially closed, causing:

  • Narrowed glottic airway causing respiratory distress and stridor
  • Intact adduction and tensioning (via cricothyroid) cause the voice to remain normal or near-normal

This is supported by the Wagner and Grossman hypothesis, which explains preservation of voice in bilateral abductor paralysis due to intact tensioning of the cords.

Explanation for other options:

Poor quality of voice (Option A): Poor voice is expected in adductor paralysis (e.g., unilateral/bilateral RLN + SLN injury), not in isolated abductor paralysis. Here, the voice is preserved.

Respiratory distress (Option B): While respiratory distress is present, stridor and preserved voice are also important and more specific features.

Respiratory distress with poor quality of voice (Option C): Voice quality is not poor in bilateral abductor palsy. This choice falsely implies adductor involvement.

questions.text: A patient presents six months after lateral skull base surgery with persistent aphonia and aspiration. No clinical improvement has been observed during the postoperative period. What is the preferred management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medialisation Thyroplasty (Type 1 Thyroplasty) is the definitive treatment for adductor paralysis of the vocal cord, which is the case in the above-given clinical scenario.

The most likely diagnosis is high vagal (combined) paralysis due to injury involving both the recurrent laryngeal nerve and the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during lateral skull base surgery.

This leads to bilateral adductor palsy:

  • All intrinsic laryngeal muscles are paralysed.
  • Vocal cords rest in the cadaveric position (neither fully open nor closed).
  • Results in:
    • Aphonia: Due to failure of cord approximation.
    • Aspiration: Due to complete laryngeal anaesthesia and open glottis.

Management:

1. Medialisation Thyroplasty (Type I Thyroplasty): Preferred definitive surgical option that brings vocal cords closer to midline and improves voice and prevents aspiration.

2. Tracheostomy: May be needed initially for protection against aspiration and clearance of secretions.

Explanation for other options:

Arytenoidectomy (Option B): For bilateral abductor palsy, not adductor palsy.

Kashima Operation (Option C): Used in bilateral abductor palsy, especially for posterior glottic stenosis (laser cordotomy).

Type II Thyroplasty (Option D): Used to lateralize the vocal cords in bilateral abductor palsy, worsening aspiration here.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient has developed a choked voice. On fiberoptic stroboscopy of the larynx, he is found to have hyperadduction of the true vocal cords while phonating. What is the name of this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These are characteristic features of Adductor Spasmodic Dysphonia, which is caused by spasms of the adductor muscles (e.g., thyroarytenoid and lateral cricoarytenoid), leading to excessive closure of the vocal cords during speech.

Spasmodic Dysphonia

  • Aetiology is uncertain, but one should exclude neurological conditionssuch as Parkinsonism, myoclonus, pseudobulbar palsy, multiple sclerosis, cerebellar disorders, tardive dyskinesia and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • Earlier, disease was considered to be psychological in origin, but psychotherapy was not found to be useful.
  • Treatment includes speech therapy with botulinum toxininjections.

questions.text: The given image is of a CO2 laser-assisted surgical procedure done in a case of bilateral abductor palsy. What is the name of this surgical procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given picture shows the Kashima operation.

  • Soft tissue at the junction of the membranous cord and the vocal process of the arytenoid is excised laterally with a CO2 laser so that there is some space created for the airway.
  • Also called as transverse cordotomy.
  • Done for bilateral abductor palsy.

Explanation for other options:

Woodman's operation (Option A) is an arytenoidectomy by open approach.

Type 1 thyroplasty (Option C) is done in the case of bilateral adductor palsy.

Type 2 thyroplasty (Option D) is done for bilateral abductor palsy, but the quality of voice is not good.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient has suddenly developed aphonia. Her laryngeal endoscopy picture shows immobile cords as shown in the picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical conditions and image attributes of bilateral adductor palsy

  • Both vocal cords are lying immobile in the intermediate or cadaveric position, and there is no adduction. So, the diagnosis is bilateral adductor palsy.
  • Caused by bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury due to neurological disorders (e.g., MND, multiple system atrophy) or Post-surgical (thyroid/parathyroid surgery),
  • Causes a breathy, weak, hoarse, or aphonic voice due to the inability of the vocal cords to adduct.
  • Aspiration risk is high in this condition.

Explanation for other options:

Phonaesthenia (Option C): This is voice fatigue, not complete loss. The cords appear normal on endoscopy.

Functional Aphonia (Option D): Typically has normal endoscopy (cords appear normal, but don't move during phonation). Often seen in psychogenic disorders, and the cords move normally with coughing.

questions.text:
A 32 year old vegetable hawker has developed hoarse voice for last 1 month. His endoscopy picture is shown in image

What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
VOCAL NODULES - Singer's / Screamer's nodules

  • Bilateral and symmetrical.
  • SITE - On the free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3 with posterior 2/3rd as this is the area of maximum vibration and hence maximum trauma.
  • Trauma to the vocal cord -> Oedema and haemorrhage in submucosal space -> Hyalinization and fibrosis -> Nodule

VOCAL POLYP-

  • Unilateral
  • Same position as vocal nodule

GRANULOMA OR CONTACT ULCER -

  • unilateral or bilateral ulcers on the vocal processes of arytenoids with mucosal congestion.

SACCULAR CYST - presents as a cyst in laryngeal ventricle

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, pg. no: 352- 354

questions.text: Posterior Triangular gap between the cords is seen in cases of weakness of :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior triangular defect is seen in interarytenoid weakness

Phonasthenia

  • It is a weakness of voice due to fatigue of the phonatory muscles - the thyroarytenoid and interarytenoids, or both.
  • The patient complains of easy fatigability of the voice.
  • Indirect laryngoscopy shows three characteristic findings:
    1. Elliptical defect: Thyroarytenoid weakness (Option A ruled out)
    2. Posterior triangular defect:Interarytenoid weakness
    3. Keyhole glottis: Thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid weakness (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Bowed down vocal cords are seen in paralysis of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cord, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • Paralysis of this muscle leads to shortening of the vocal cord with loss of tension, bowing down of the vocal cords, and hence loss of pitch of voice.
  • In unilateral palsy, the anterior commissure is rotated towards the normal side, which is called Askew Glottis.
  • The sensory supply of the larynx to the vocal cords is by the internal branch of the SLN. The loss of this supply can lead to aspiration.
  • These symptoms are more pronounced in bilateral nerve damage.

Paralysis of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

questions.text: The most common cause of bilateral vocal cord palsy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thyroid surgery (Total thyroidectomy) is the most common cause of bilateral vocal cord palsy.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerves are vulnerable during total thyroidectomy, especially if both sides are operated on.
  • If both RLNs are injured, cords are fixed in the paramedian position, leading to airway obstruction but preserved voice.
  • A tracheostomy is often required in such cases.
  • The most common cause of unilateral vocal cord palsy is idiopathic, followed by carcinoma bronchus. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Though carcinoma thyroid can involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, it usually causes unilateral (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: : A 50-year-old female presents with a history of progressive breathlessness and noisy breathing over several months. On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords are seen in a paramedian position and fail to abduct during inspiration. Which of the following statements about bilateral abductor vocal cord paralysis is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cords lie in cadaveric position in complete vagal paralysis but not in bilateral abductor vocal cord paralysis.

Bilateral Abductor Vocal Cord Paralysis

In this condition, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles, which are only abductors of the vocal cords, are paralysed due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).

Pathophysiology:

  • Abductors are paralysed. So, cords cannot move laterally (open). But adductors remain intact. So, cords are pulled medially.
  • Thus, vocal cords lie in the paramedian position as partially closed.
  • Cadaveric position is halfway between abduction and adduction.
  • It occurs when both abductors and adductors are paralysed, such as in complete vagal paralysis.
  • In isolated abductor paralysis, adductors still act, pulling the cords medially to the paramedian position.

Most common causes include:

  • Surgical trauma (e.g. post-thyroidectomy)
  • Neuritis or compressive lesions involving the RLN

Voice Quality:

  • Voice is usually preserved or only mildly affected. (Option A is true)
  • Because the cords are near the midline, phonation can still occur effectively.

Breathing Difficulty:

  • Stridor (noisy breathing) is the hallmark. (Option B is true)
  • May present as exertional dyspnea or worsening during respiratory infections.

Management:

  • Tracheostomy may be urgently required (Option D is true)
    • In case of airway compromise
    • During acute upper respiratory tract infections
  • Definitive management includes cord lateralisation procedures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male professional singer presents with a complaint of an abnormally high-pitched voice that is inconsistent with his age and gender. He has normal vocal cord mobility and no structural lesions on laryngoscopy. A diagnosis of puberphonia (mutational falsetto) is made, and conservative voice therapy has failed. The patient is now being considered for phonosurgical correction. Which of the following types of thyroplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type III thyroplasty is done for vocal cord shortening in puberphonia.

  • By removing a midline vertical strip of thyroid cartilage and allowing the thyroid lamina to buckle inward, the vocal cords are relaxed and shortened, lowering the pitch.

choices.text: A cough sound is usually normal
Speech therapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a sudden loss of voice for 3 weeks. She can cough and laugh normally, but no sound comes out when she tries to speak. She has no history of recent illness, trauma, or surgery. On laryngoscopy, her vocal cords appear structurally normal and mobile, but there is no adduction during phonation. Neurologic and ENT examinations are otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following statements about functional aphonia is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for functional aphonia. Speech therapy is not needed as there is no organic cause.

Functional aphonia (hysterical aphonia)

  • Psychological disease seen in emotionally labile females (15-30 yrs)(Option B ruled out)
  • Aphonia is usually sudden.
  • The patient communicates in a whisper.
  • Vocal cords are seen in an abducted position and fail to adduct on phonation but adduct on coughing, indicating normal adductor function. (Option D ruled out)
  • The sound of the cough is good. (Option A ruled out)
  • Treatment - Psychotherapy
